GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 64Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 10-12 weeks. Pick before flowering.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Tomato
AdditionalInfo: Basil is commonly used fresh in cooked recipes. It is generally added at the last moment, as cooking quickly destroys the flavour. Tear rather than chop. The fresh herb can be kept for a short time in plastic bags in the refrigerator, or for a longer period in the freezer, after being blanched quickly in boiling water.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 45Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Onions, Silverbeet (Swiss Chard), Lettuce, Cabbage, Dwarf Beans, Dill, Peas. Strawberries
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Asparagus, Carrots, Sweetcorn, Spinach
AdditionalInfo: Apart from boiling whole for salads, beetroot roast well, cut in wedges. They also make a tasty salad grated raw with carrot and a little fresh orange juice.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 8-10 weeks. Use leaves before flowers appear, otherwise they will be 'hairy'. .
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Strawberry, tomatoes, zucchini/squash. Deters pests from many plants.
AdditionalInfo: Has a slight cucumber taste which goes well in salads and when cooked with silver beet or cabbage. The flowers make a pretty drink decoration when frozen in an iceblock.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 43Â°F and 75Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 12-22 weeks. Pick frequently to encourage more pods.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Dill, Potatoes
AdditionalInfo: The fresh beans are eaten steamed or boiled. As the beans mature it is better to remove their tough outer skins after cooking. The leafy top shoots of the adult plants can be picked and steamed after flowering. Small beans can be eaten whole in the pods.
column10: Will freeze well. Remove from pods and blanch.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 45Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 10-16 weeks. Cut flowerhead off with a knife..
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Dwarf (bush) beans, beets, celery, cucumber, onions, marigold, nasturtium, rhubarb, aromatic herbs (sage, dill, chamomile, oregano)
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chilli, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: The stem (peeled), leaves, and flowerhead are all edible. Steam for best flavour. Peel large stalks, slice and steam. Goes well with blue cheese sauce.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 45Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 14-28 weeks. Pick sprouts when small. .
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Dwarf (bush) beans, beets, celery, cucumber, onions, marigold, nasturtium, rhubarb, aromatic herbs (sage, dill, chamomile)
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chili, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: Remove any discoloured outer leaves. Cut in half and steam with other vegetables. Do not overcook as that produces the distinctive smell that puts people off eating Brussels sprouts! They go well with a chopped tomato and onion mix.Traditionally served with roasted chestnuts for Xmas dinner in UK.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Best grown in separate bed.
AdditionalInfo: Harvest in the first year when the burdock root is very crisp and has a sweet, mild, and pungent flavour with a little muddy harshness that can be reduced by soaking julienne/shredded roots in water for five to ten minutes. Immature flower stalks may also be harvested in late spring, before flowers appear; the taste resembles that of artichoke, to which the burdock is related. It is a key ingredient in the traditional Dandelion and Burdock beer.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 41Â°F and 64Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Dwarf (bush) beans, beets, celery, cucumber, onions, marigold, nasturtium, rhubarb, aromatic herbs (sage, dill, chamomile, thyme)
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chili, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard, parsnip
AdditionalInfo: Young spring cabbage can be chopped and added to salad greens. Steaming preserves the goodness and flavour of cabbage. Can also be used in stir-fry. Red cabbage chopped and cooked with brown sugar, red wine, onions, vinegar and stock is served with boiled bacon or pork.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Will happily grow in a flower border
AdditionalInfo: The berry is the size of a cherry tomato, is very aromatic and full of tiny seeds. They are delicious eaten fresh or can be made into jam. They can be added to salads, desserts and cooked dishes, they are delicious stewed with other fruit, especially apples. They also go well in savoury dishes with meat or seafood.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 64Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 10-12 weeks. Cut fruit off with sharp knife.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Egg plant (Aubergine), Nasturtiums, Basil, Parsley, Amaranth
AdditionalInfo: Can be sliced and seeded and used raw in salads. Or brush with olive oil, roast at a high temperature until the skin changes colour then put in a covered dish until cool and rub off the skin and remove seeds.
column10: Will freeze successfully without blanching if seeded and sliced.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 55Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Best grown in separate bed.
AdditionalInfo: Cut off the base and leaves, then cut the stalks into pieces. Boil the stalks for around 20 minutes until tender: drain, and peel off the surface of the stalks. Add precooked cardoons to a variety of dishes, they go well with mushrooms.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Onions, Leeks, Lettuce, Sage, Peas, Radishes, Tomatoes, Beans, Celery, Rosemary
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Parsnips, Beetroot, Dill, Brassicas, Fennel
AdditionalInfo: Steamed or raw carrots are tasty. Cook them in a small amount of water until nearly dry then add a pat of butter and teasp of brown sugar to glaze. They can be added to most casserole-type dishes. Grate raw carrots and add to salads

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)

IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chili, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: Cauliflower can be steamed. Young ones can be broken into small pieces and added raw to salad. Cook briefly and add to curry mix. Traditionally served with cheese sauce. Add tomato slices for colour.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 70Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Beans, brassicas, carrots, leeks, lettuce, peas, sage, tomatoes, onions
AdditionalInfo: Cook whole, scrubbed and peeled. Or slice or dice.Tastes like celery.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 54Â°F and 70Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Not applicable as celery needs to be close together to encourage blanching.
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Sweetcorn
AdditionalInfo: Chop and use raw in salad or braised in hot dishes.

GrowInstruction: Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 16-24 weeks. Will need forcing before final harvest.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Carrots, onions, Florence fennel, tomatoes.
AdditionalInfo: Good in salads. Grill lightly with butter. Bake with ham and cheese.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 64Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 9-11 weeks. Wear gloves to pick 'hot' chilies.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Best grown in a separate bed as chillis need plenty of light and air circulation.
AdditionalInfo: Wash, dry, and free whole. Use them direct from the freezer (no need to defrost). Wear plastic gloves or wash your hands thoroughly after handling and cutting to avoid accidentally rubbing chilli juice onto your mouth or eyes!

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow direct in the garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 8-10 weeks. Harvest whole head or you can take a few leaves at a time.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Dwarf (bush) beans, beets, celery, cucumber, onions, marigold, nasturtium, rhubarb, aromatic herbs (sage, dill, chamomile, coriander), lettuce, potatoes
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chilli, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: Use in stir-fry . Has a milder flavour than regular cabbage.Shred the inner leaves and stems to use in coleslaw salad.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Carrots, Tomatoes, Parsley, Apples
AdditionalInfo: Use raw in salads or as a mild onion flavour in cooked dishes.

HarvestDuration: Harvest in approximately 17 weeks. Best when fruit is light green and not more than 6cm long.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Cucumbers
AdditionalInfo: Chokos can be peeled and chopped to use in stews, soup or as a stir fry vegetable. Cooked or raw, it has a very mild flavour and is commonly served with seasonings e.g., salt, butter and pepper or in a dish with other vegetables and/or flavourings. It can also be boiled, stuffed, mashed or pickled

AlternatePlantName: Pole beans, Runner beans, Scarlet Runners

IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Alliums (Chives, leek, garlic, onions), Florence fennel
AdditionalInfo: Use young in salads - blanch and cool.

column10: The seeds can be dried and ground up for curries.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Onions
AdditionalInfo: Pick individual leaves or harvest the whole plant as required

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. When soil begins to warm up. After frosts finish.. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 59Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
AdditionalInfo: Young leaves can be cooked and used like spinach and are very high in protein. The young pods are edible.

GrowInstruction: Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 61Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)

IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Potato, Tomatoes
AdditionalInfo: Pick frequently before the fruit become too big. Use raw in salads, peeled if preferred.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Direct in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 8-10 weeks. Dig daikon carefully. They are rather brittle..
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Chervil, cress,lettuce, leeks, spinach, strawberries, tomatoes
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Gherkins, hyssop
AdditionalInfo: Daikon radish can be eaten simmered, stir fried, grated, pickled or baked. Its leaves are also edible and can be used in recipes that call for turnip greens, and its seeds make sprouts to eat in salads or in sandwiches.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 68Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 8-12 weeks. Use leaves before flowering.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Cabbage, Coriander, Fennel, tomatoes, broccoli
AdditionalInfo: Dill leaves can be used fresh or dried in salads, meats, vegetable dishes and soups. Freshly cut leaves enhance the flavour of dips, herb butter, soups, salads, fish dishes, and salads. Both the flowering heads and seeds are used in flavoured vinegars and oils. Used whole or ground, the seeds add zest to bread, cheese, and salad dressing.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 61Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 7-10 weeks. Pick often to encourage more flower production.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Sweetcorn, spinach, lettuce, summer savory, dill, carrots, brassicas, beets, radish, strawberry and cucumbers, tagates minuta (wild marigold)
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Alliums (Chives, leek, garlic, onions) Sunflower
AdditionalInfo: Can be used in salads when young, blanched and cooled.

GrowInstruction: Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 75Â°F and 90Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 12-15 weeks. Cut fruit with scissors or sharp knife.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Beans, capsicum, lettuce, amaranth, thyme
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Potatoes
AdditionalInfo: Cut and use the same day if possible. Slice, no need to peel, and fry in olive oil. Brush with oil and grill or bake. Or microwave,plain, for about 4 minutes on high. Makes a good substitute for pasta in lasagne or moussaka. Can be smoked over a gas ring or barbecue, cooled and peeled and used to make dips.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 59Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): beans, brassicas, carrots, cucumbers, chervil, sage.
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Alliums (garlic and onions)
AdditionalInfo: Very tasty topped with grated swiss cheese and grilled for a couple of minutes to crisp up the cheese and wilt the leaves. Can use in salads additional to lettuce, but needs a flavoursome dressing if you aren't overly fond of bitterness.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Best grown away from vegetables
AdditionalInfo: Cut off leaves as required Use leaves fresh or dried . Particularly good with fish. The seeds can be used in pickling mixes.

GrowInstruction: Plant cuttings or root division. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 30-40 days. Pick leaves when young for best flavour.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Aubergine (Eggplant) and Capsicum (Peppers)
AdditionalInfo: Tarragon goes well with fish, pork, beef, poultry, game, potatoes, tomatoes, carrots, and most vegetables.Ã‚ Tarragon can be used in cream sauces, herbed butters and vinegars, soups, sour creams, and yogurt. However, it can be overpowering in large amounts.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Plant cloves. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 95Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Beets, Carrots, Cucumbers, Dill, Tomatoes, Parsnips
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Asparagus, Beans, Brassicas, Peas, Potatoes
AdditionalInfo: Cut the growing shoots or use the entire young garlic plants as 'garlic greens' in stirfry.

GrowInstruction: Plant pieces of fresh root showing signs of shoots. Best planted at soil temperatures between 20Â°C and 30Â°C. (Show Â°F/in)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in approximately 25 weeks. Reduce water as plant dies back to encourage rhizome growth.
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Grow in separate bed
AdditionalInfo: Use in any recipes requiring fresh ginger. Widely used in Asian cooking, it is hot without the 'burn' of chilli.
column10: Ginger root freezes well either whole or grated, and can be used direct from the freezer in most recipes requiring fresh ginger.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Plant root pieces. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 16-24 weeks. Some improvement in flavour if left till after frost..
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Best kept separate
AdditionalInfo: Strong, spicy flavour traditionally used with roast beef. Used grated for horseradish sauce or horseradish cream

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Plant tubers about 5cm (1.5") deep.. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 59Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Tomatoes, cucumbers
AdditionalInfo: Scrape clean or peel (add a tsp of lemon or vinegar to the water to stop the tubers browning). Steam, boil, or use in artichoke soup (make with artichokes and some stock). Caution - because they contain 'resistent starch' Jerusalem Artichokes are a great promoter of flatulence in some individuals.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)

IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chilli, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: Strong flavoured and nutritious vegetable. Wash well and chop finely then steam. A tomato or cheese sauce will mask the flavour if too strong.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Beets, celery, cucumber, onions, marigold, nasturtium, rhubarb, aromatic herbs (sage, dill, chamomile)
IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Climbing (pole) beans, tomato, peppers (chilli, capsicum), eggplant (aubergine), strawberry, mustard
AdditionalInfo: Use when young. Scrub well, cut off leaf stalks, roots and woody parts. Young ones do not need peeling. Can be grated raw for salads or cut in pieces and steam. Use in casseroles.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays, and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46Â°F and 86Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)
HarvestDuration: Harvest in 15-18 weeks. Loosen with a fork rather than pull by hand..
CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Carrots
AdditionalInfo: Trim off the roots and any damaged leaves. Young ones can be used whole with some of the green leaves. Wash thoroughly as the earth tends to get inside. Chop and fry in butter (or olive oil) until tender. Can be added to casserole meals, allowing time to cook through. Leek and mushroom make a tasty combination for a tart filling.

GrowInstruction: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50Â°F and 77Â°F. (Show Â°C/cm)

CompatiblePlant: Compatible with (can grow beside): Good to attract bees
AdditionalInfo: As a herb tea or added to fruit punch. Can be used to replace lemon, used sparingly, in desserts and with stewed fruit. Chop leaves into salad. Better used fresh than dried.

AdditionalInfo: The luffa flowers and fruits are soft and edible when young and are sometimes cooked and eaten like squash or okra. Loofah has been an important food source in many Asian cultures. The leaves and vines should not be eaten.

IncompatiblePlant: Avoid growing close to: Potatoes

Sprinkle a bowl of strawberries with balsamic vinegar and a little sugar to enhance the flavour and colour.
